newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish grain imports seen at 1 mln T/yr until 2000.
newsitem.headline: Polish grain imports seen at 1 mln T/yr until 2000.

text.p: Poland is expected to import up to one million tonnes of grain per year until the year 2000, with high-gluten wheat making up a large part of the imports, a senior government-linked analyst said on Tuesday.

"In the period to the year 2000 Poland is likely to import up to one million tonnes of grain per year," Michal Kisiel, the author of the bi-annual grain markets report for the Agriculture Ministry, told a agriculture conference.

Kisiel said domestic demand for grains would rise to 27.8 million tonnes in 2000 from this year's 26.2 million, with demand for fodder grains growing to some 17.0 to 17.5 million tonnes from last year's 14.9 million.
He expected grain production to rise to above 28 million tonnes by the year 2000, from 24.7 million last year.

Kisiel said that Poland could have a surplus of about 600,000 tonnes of wheat by the end of the century, but that the country still had to import some types of wheat, such as Durhum, which were not grown domestically.
